Rosenbluth formula |awards = [[Albert Einstein Award]] (1967)
[[Enrico Fermi Award]] (1985)
[[Hannes Alfvén Prize]] (2002) |footnotes = }} '''Marshall Nicholas Rosenbluth''' (5 February 1927 – 28 September 2003) was an [[Americans|American]] [[Plasma Physics|plasma physicist]] and member of the [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]]. In 1997 he was awarded the [[National Medal of Science]] for discoveries in controlled thermonuclear fusion, contributions to [[plasma physics]], and work in computational [[statistical mechanics]]. He was also a recipient of the [[Ernest Lawrence|E.O. Lawrence]] Prize (1964), the [[Albert Einstein Award]] (1967), the [[James Clerk Maxwell Prize]] in Plasma Physics (1976), the [[Enrico Fermi Award]] (1985), and the [[Hannes Alfvén Prize]] (2002). ==Key scientific contributions== During his first post-doctoral position at [[Stanford University]] (1949–1950), he derived the ''Rosenbluth formula'', which was the basis of the analysis used by [[Robert Hofstadter]] in his Nobel prize-winning experimental investigation of [[electron scattering]]. Hofstadter refers to this in his 1961 [[Nobel Lecture]]: "This behavior can be understood in terms of the theoretical scattering law developed by M. Rosenbluth in 1950". In 1953, Rosenbluth derived the [[Metropolis algorithm]]; cited in ''Computing in Science and Engineering'' (Jan. 2000) as being among the top 10 algorithms having the "greatest influence on the development and practice of science and engineering in the 20th century." However, by the late 1950s, Rosenbluth turned his attention to the burgeoning discipline of plasma physics and quickly laid the foundation for many avenues of research in the field, particularly the theory of [[plasma instabilities]]. Although he continued to work on plasma physics for the remainder of his career, he often made forays into other fields. For example, around 1980, he and coworkers produced a detailed analysis of the [[free electron laser]], indicating how its spectral intensity can be optimized. He maintained a high productivity rate throughout his entire career. Indeed, only a few years before his death, Rosenbluth discovered the existence of residual flows (so-called ''Rosenbluth-Hinton flows''), a key result for understanding turbulence in [[tokamak]]s. ==Early years== Rosenbluth graduated from [[Stuyvesant High School]] in 1942.{{cite web |url=http://www.utexas.edu/faculty/council/2004-2005/memorials/rosenbluth/rosenbluth.html |title=In Memoriam - Marshall N. Rosenbluth |date=2004-09-24 |publisher=[[UT Austin]] |author=Larry R. Faulkner|author2=Sue Alexander Greninger |accessdate=2007-10-31}} He did his undergraduate study at Harvard, graduating in 1946 (B.S., [[Phi Beta Kappa]]), despite also serving in the [[U.S. Navy]] (1944–46) during this period. He received his Ph.D. in 1949 from the [[University of Chicago]]. In 1950, [[Edward Teller]], considered the father of the [[hydrogen bomb]], recruited Rosenbluth to work at [[Los Alamos National Laboratory|Los Alamos]].Teller, Edward, The Work of Many People, Science, New Series, Vol. 121, No. 3139 (Feb. 25, 1955), pp. 267-275, page 271 Rosenbluth maintained this position until 1956. The research he conducted at Los Alamos led to the development of the H-bomb. {{quote|... Rosenbluth went to the [[Ivy Mike|South Pacific to prepare for the first H-bomb test]]. He had trouble sleeping, and was pondering the bomb design when he realised the scientists had made a calculating error that could result in a dud. The flaw was remedied by modifying the detonator, and the bomb vaporised a [[mile]]-wide island with a power 700 times greater than that of the [[Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki|atom bomb dropped on Hiroshima]] in 1945.{{cite newspaper|author=Wright, Pearce|authorlink=Pearce Wright|newspaper=The Guardian|title=Obituary. Marshall Rosenbluth|date=4 October 2003|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2003/oct/04/guardianobituaries.highereducation1}}}} ==Additional information== Upon his retirement, he took on the responsibility of chief scientist of the Central Team for the [[ITER|International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor]] (ITER) until 1999. Rosenbluth also served as a member of the [[JASON Defense Advisory Group]]. Rosenbluth was affectionately known as the ''Pope of Plasma Physics'' in reference to his deep understanding of the field.Kim A. McDonald, [http://www.universityofcalifornia.edu/news/article/5780 Nuclear Fusion Pioneer At UC San Diego Dies At 76] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110323120425/http://www.universityofcalifornia.edu/news/article/5780 |date=2011-03-23 }}, obituary at the [[University of California]] website. Beichl and F. Sullivan, [https://hua-zhou.github.io/teaching/st758-2014fall/top10/metropolis.pdf "The Metropolis Algorithm"], ''Computing in Science and Engineering'', Volume 2, Number 1, Jan/Feb 2000. {{doi|10.1109/5992.814660}} * J.E. Gubernatis, [http://www.dsf.unica.it/~fiore/GoR.pdf "Marshall Rosenbluth and the Metropolis Algorithm"], ''[[Physics of Plasmas]]'', 12, 057303 (2005). {{doi|10.1063/1.1887186}} * {{cite journal |first1=N. |last1=Metropolis |authorlink1=Nicholas Metropolis |first2=A.W. |last2=Rosenbluth |authorlink2=Arianna W. '''Shlomo S. Sawilowsky''' is [[professor]] of educational statistics and Distinguished Faculty Fellow at [[Wayne State University]] in [[Detroit]], Michigan, where he has received teaching, mentoring, and research awards.<ref>[http://www.otl.wayne.edu/awardsWSU/aw-pe.html 1994 WSU President's Award For Excellence In Teaching; 1997 College of Education Excellence in Teaching Award] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081106104005/http://www.otl.wayne.edu/awardsWSU/aw-pe.html |date=2008-11-06 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.gradschool.wayne.edu/GradCouncil/archives/97-98/98-03-25min.pdf 1998 WSU Outstanding Graduate Mentor Award]</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100627233059/http://www.coe.wayne.edu/COE/pdf_files/08-09-Educator-v4.pdf 2000 - 2002 WSU Distinguished Faculty Fellow.]</ref>

==Academic career==
Sawilowsky obtained his [[Ph.D.]] in 1985 at the [[University of South Florida]]. He was inducted into the USF chapter of the [[Phi Kappa Phi]] honor society on May 17, 1981,<ref>''Who's Who in American Education'', 1990, ''II'', 608. National Reference Institute.</ref> when he received his [[Master of Arts|M.A.]]<ref name="coe.wayne.edu">{{cite web|url=http://coe.wayne.edu/faculty-staff/bio.php?id=60321|title=Profile View - College of Education - Wayne State University|publisher=}}</ref> In 2008 Sawilowsky served as president of the [[American Educational Research Association]] Special Interest Group/Educational Statisticians. He served as Assistant Dean in the College of Education at WSU for several years. Along with Miodrag Lovric (Serbia) and [[C. R. Rao]] (India), he was nominated for the 2013 [[Nobel Peace Prize]] for his contributions to the [[International Encyclopedia of Statistical Science]].<ref>http://www.ime.usp.br/~abe/lista/pdfcFHNhReNSn.pdf</ref>

==Contributions to applied statistics and social/behavioral sciences==
In 2000, the ''AMSTAT News'', a publication of the [[American Statistical Association]], described Professor Sawilowsky's award of Distinguished Faculty Fellow "in recognition of Sawilowsky's outstanding scholarly achievements in applied statistics, psychometrics, and experimental design in education and psychology."<ref>''Amstat News'', May, 2000, p. 26.</ref>

===Applied statistics===
He is the author of a statistics textbook that presents statistical methods via Monte Carlo simulation methods,<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sawilowsky |first1=Shlomo S. |last2=Fahoome |first2=Gail C. |year=2003 |title=''Statistics via Monte Carlo Simulation with Fortran'' |publisher=Rochester Hills, MI: JMASM |isbn=978-0-9740236-0-1}}</ref> editor of a volume on real data analysis published by the [[American Educational Research Association]] SIG/Educational Statisticians,<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sawilowsky |first1=Shlomo S. (Ed.) |year= 2007 |title=Real Data Analysis: A Volume in Quantitative Methods in Education and the Behavioral Sciences: Issues, Research, and Teaching. American Educational Research Association SIG Educational Statisticians |publisher=Charlotte, NC: IAP-Information Age Publishing |isbn=978-1-59311-565-4}}</ref> and author of over a hundred articles in applied statistics and social sciences journals. Sawilowsky has also authored 24 entries in statistics encyclopedias.

His presentation titled "The Rank Transform," with co-author R. Clifford Blair, was awarded the 1985 Florida Educational Research Association & 1986 American Educational Research Association State/Regions Distinguished Paper Award.<ref name="coe.wayne.edu"/> Many of his publications are related to [[Ranking#Ranking in statistics|rank-based]] [[nonparametric statistics]]. For example, an examination of the robustness and comparative power properties of the rank transform statistic<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sawilowsky |first1=Shlomo S. |last2=Blair |first2=R. C.|last3=Higgins |first3=J. J.|title=An investigation of the type I error and power properties of the rank transform procedure in factorial ANOVA|journal=Journal of Educational Statistics|volume=14|issue=3 |pages=255–267|doi=10.3102/10769986014003255|year=1989 }}</ref> was called a "major Monte Carlo study".<ref name="Het98">{{cite book|last1=Hettmansperger|first1=T. P.|last2=McKean|first2=J. W.|title=Robust nonparametric statistical methods| edition=First|series=Kendall's Library of Statistics |volume=5 |location=London|publisher=Edward Arnold; New York: John Wiley \& Sons, Inc. |year=1998|pages=xiv, 269–270, 467|isbn=978-0-340-54937-7 |mr=1604954}}.</ref><ref>Similarly, see F. Pesarin (2001), ''Multivariate permutation tests'', Chichester: Wiley, p. 229.</ref> Hettmansperger and McKean stated that Sawilowsky provided "an excellent review of nonparametric approaches to testing for interaction" (p. 254-255).<ref name=Het98/>

Sawilowsky's Monte Carlo work has been cited as an exemplar for designing simulation studies.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Maxwell | first1 = S. E. | last2 = Cole | first2 = D. A. | year = 1995 | title = Tips for writing (and reading) methodological papers | url = http://business.nmsu.edu/~mhyman/M610_Articles/Maxwell_Psych_Bulletin_1995.pdf | journal = Psychological Bulletin | volume = 118 | issue = 2| pages = 196–197 | doi=10.1037/0033-2909.118.2.193| citeseerx = 10.1.1.417.6968 }}</ref> His work has been cited on a variety of statistical issues, such as
*demonstrating sequential procedures of testing underlying assumptions of parametric tests, commonly recommended in textbooks and statistics software user manuals, "increases the rate of Type I error";<ref>Grissom, R. J., & Kim, J. J. (2005). ''Effect sizes for research: A broach practical approach''. Mahwah, NJ: Erlbaum, p. 15.</ref>
*rounding down degrees of freedom when using tabled critical values decreases statistical power;<ref>Grissom & Kim (2005), p. 33</ref>
* alternatives to the winsorized sample standard deviation can be invoked to increase the statistical power of Yuen's confidence interval;<ref>Grissom & Kim (2005), p. 38</ref>
*[[maximum likelihood]] methods (e.g., one-step Huber) are superior to trimming in constructing robust estimators;<ref>Grissom & Kim (2005), p. 42</ref>
*using effect sizes obtained when the null hypothesis has been retained inflates Type I errors in meta-analysis;<ref>Grissom & Kim (2005), p. 60</ref> and
*setting the standards for an appropriate Monte Carlo simulation.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Cassey | last2 = Smith | year = 2014 | title = Simulating confidence for the Ellison-Glaeser Index | url = | journal = Journal of Urban Economics | volume = 81 | issue = | page = 93 | doi =  10.1016/j.jue.2014.02.005}}</ref><ref>Grissom & Kim (2005), p. 131</ref>

{{See also|Monte Carlo Methods}}

===Psychometrics===
In [[psychological testing]], Sawilowsky is a co-author of two [[Self-determination theory|self-determination]] <!--standardized --> [[Psychological assessment|assessment]] batteries;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ealyeducation.com/|title=Self-Determination Assessment-internet|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sdtac.uncc.edu/sd_assessments.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-03-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100628223252/http://www.sdtac.uncc.edu/sd_assessments.asp |archivedate=2010-06-28 |df= }}</ref> an instrument designed to assess [[locus of control]], [[self-esteem]], and [[self-concept]] among at-risk adolescents;<ref>Wood, P. C, Hillman, S. B., & Sawilowsky, S. S. (1996). Locus of control, self-concept, and self-esteem among at-risk African -American adolescents. ''Tests in Print'', Volume 1, Oscar Krisen Buros, Buros Institute of Mental Measurements, Educational tests and measurements, 1999, p. 247.</ref> an instrument "which measures [[future orientation]], knowledge of the realities of child rearing, personal intentions, and sexual self-efficacy;"<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Herrman | first1 = J. W. | last2 = Waterhouse | first2 = J. K. | year = 2010 | title = What do adolescents think about teen parenting? | url = | journal = Western Journal of Nursing Research | volume =  33| issue = 4| pages =  577–592| doi = 10.1177/0193945910381761 | pmid = 20947793 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Somers | first1 = C. L. | last2 = Johnson | first2 = S. A. | last3 = Sawilowsky | first3 = S. S. | year = 2002 | title = A measure for evaluating the effectiveness of teen pregnancy programs | url = | journal = Psychology in the Schools | volume = 39 | issue = 3| pages = 337–342 | doi=10.1002/pits.10023}}</ref> and a college well-being instrument.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.edgefoundation.org/information/research/edge-research-executive-summary/|title=Edge Research Executive Summary|publisher=|access-date=2010-12-09|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110118021239/http://www.edgefoundation.org/information/research/edge-research-executive-summary/|archive-date=2011-01-18|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Sawilowsky was the initial proponent in favor of psychometric theory (reliability refers to the test) over datametric theory<ref>Sawilowsky coined the phrase "datametric theory" in {{cite journal | last1 = Sawilowsky | first1 = S | year = 2000 | title = Psychometrics vs datametrics. | journal = Educational and Psychological Measurement| volume= 60| issue = 2 |pages= 157–173 | doi=10.1177/00131640021970439}}; see also {{cite journal | last1 = Sawilowsky | first1 = S. |year=2000| journal = Educational and Psychological Measurement | volume = 60 | issue = 2| pages = 196–200 | doi=10.1177/00131640021970457 | title=Reliability: Rejoinder to Thompson and Vacha-Haase}}</ref> (reliability refers to the data), a controversy with implications for test theory, role of tests in expert testimony, [[test validity]],<ref>S. Urbina (2004), ''Essentials of psychological testing''. Hoboken: Wiley, p. 148.</ref><ref>Note that in classical measurement theory (see, e.g., Sawilowsky (2000), ''Educational and Psychological Measurement''), validity applies to the application of the test, but not to the test itself. Hence, the Wikipedia link name is problematic.</ref> etc. The debate was discussed in ''Educational and Psychological Measurement''<ref>2000, ''v''. 60</ref> and elsewhere.<ref>B. Thompson (Ed.) (2003), ''Score reliability: Contemporary thinking on reliability issues'', Thousand Oaks: Sage.</ref> Although the issue has not been resolved, the current non-aligned opinion "lean[s] toward the Sawilowsky position."<ref>J. C. Thomas and P. Traux (2008), Assessment and analysis of clinically significant change. In D. McKay (Ed.), ''Handbook of Research Methods in Abnormal and Clinical Psychology'', p. 333.</ref> In [[classical test theory]], he developed the ''Sawilowsky I'' test, a statistical test used to help demonstrate evidence of [[construct validity]] in the [[multitrait-multimethod matrix]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Sawilowsky | first1 = S | year = 2002 | title = A quick distribution-free test for trend that contributes evidence of construct validity | url = | journal = Measurement and Evaluation in Counseling and Development | volume = 35 | issue = | pages = 78–88 }}</ref>

{{See also| Multitrait-multimethod matrix}}

===Experimental design===
Sawilowsky's Monte Carlo<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sawilowsky |first1=Shlomo S. (Ed.) |year= 2007 |title=Real Data Analysis: A Volume in Quantitative Methods in Education and the Behavioral Sciences: Issues, Research, and Teaching. American Educational Research Association SIG Educational Statisticians |publisher=Charlotte, NC: IAP-Information Age Publishing |isbn=978-1-59311-565-4}}, Chapter 15</ref> work on comparing randomized vs quasi-experimental design has been described as "one of the strongest examples" <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Spence|first1=P. R.|author2=Lachlan, K. A.|author3=Rainear|first3=Adam|title=Social media and crisis research: Data collection and directions|journal=Computers in Human Behavior|volume=54|date=2016|pages=667–672|doi=10.1016/j.chb.2015.08.045}}</ref> demonstrating limitations of quasi-experimental design, and "provides possibly one of the strongest cases for the superiority of randomized designs."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Spence|first=P. R.|author2=Lachlan, K. A. |title=Disasters, crises, and unique populations: Suggestions for survey research|journal=New Directions for Evaluation|volume=2010|issue=126|date=2010|pages=95–106|doi=10.1002/ev.332}}</ref>

==Mentorship==
In 1998, the ''AMSTAT News'' reported Sawilowsky's Awards for Excellence in Teaching, and Graduate Mentorship, and noted "Professor Sawilowsky's exceptional record as an academician is reflected in the excellence with which he mentors graduate students."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amstat.org/sections/educ/award.html|title=Awards for Outstanding Statistics Educators|publisher=}}</ref> He has mentored 91 doctoral dissertations as major professor according to the [[Mathematics Genealogy Project]].<ref name=genealogy/> 

[[ProQuest]] indicates he has chaired dissertations in many other fields, such as kinesiology,<ref>ProQuest 1594489921</ref> nursing education,<ref>ProQuest 1269394702</ref> and teacher education;<ref>ProQuest 1269395621</ref> and co-chaired a dissertation on process drama.<ref>Proquest 733505421</ref> He also served as 2nd advisor on many doctoral dissertations, and numerous more as a committee member.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://coe.wayne.edu/tbf/eer/bio.php?id=60321|title=Profile View - College of Education - Wayne State University|publisher=}}</ref>

==Editorship==
Sawilowsky is the founder and editor of the ''[[Journal of Modern Applied Statistical Methods]].'' It was created to provide an outlet for research using Monte Carlo and other resampling methods, nonparametric and other robust methods, permutation and other exact or approximately exact methods, and statistical algorithms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://digitalcommons.wayne.edu/jmasm/|title=JMASM: Journal of Modern Applied Statistical Methods - Open Access Journals - Wayne State University|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jmasm.com|title=Journal of Modern Applied Statistical Methods (JMASM)|publisher=}}</ref>

==Rabbinical studies and contributions to the Judaica literature==
After graduating from the [[Rabbinical College of America]] in 1979, Sawilowsky was the emissary of the Grand Rabbi of Lubavitch, Rabbi [[Menachem Mendel Schneerson]], to [[Pinellas County, Florida]].<ref>Rabbi Yosef B. Friedman (Ed.)(1986). ''Let there be light: Thirty days in the lives of the Chabad-Lubavitch Lamplighters''. Brooklyn, NY: Merkos L'Inyonei Chinuch, Section "Florida: S. Petersburg," {{ISBN|0-8266-0378-5}}.</ref> He also obtained a rabbinical degree from Yeshivas Pirchei Shoshanim ([[Jerusalem]], [[Israel]]) in 2004, after having studied with the first group of students ever to receive strictly Orthodox Rabbinical [[Semicha|ordination]] curricula on the laws of the [[Shabbat|Jewish Sabbath]] delivered via e-mail.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070214062405/http://www.shemayisrael.com/smicha/alumni.htm Shema Yisrael Torah Learning Network]</ref><ref>[http://mishpacha.com/backissuesLarge/1/14/ ''Mishpacha Jewish Family Weekly''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061111060729/http://mishpacha.com/backissuesLarge/1/14/ |date=November 11, 2006 }}</ref>

Sawilowsky is the author of a textbook written in dialogue format for preparing food and other matters related to the kitchen for the Sabbath.<ref>Sawilowsky, Shlomo S. (2007). ''Making the Shabbos kitchen''. (With editorial assistance by Yechiel Conway.) Lakewood, NJ: Pirchei Shoshanim. {{ISBN|978-0-9740236-7-0}}</ref> It is based on the [[Talmud]], Code of Jewish Law ([[Shulchan Aruch]]), and [[Ashkenaz]], [[Sephardi]], and [[Chabad]] customs. He has published articles on Bible commentary and related topics in the annual journal of Pirchei Shoshanim.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>

{{about|the professor of finance|other uses}}
'''Eduardo Saul Schwartz''' (born 1940) is a professor of finance at the [[UCLA Anderson School of Management|Anderson School of Management]], [[University of California, Los Angeles]], where he holds the California Chair in Real Estate & Land Economics. He is known for pioneering research in several areas of finance, particularly [[derivative (finance)|derivatives]].<ref>[[Phelim Boyle]] (2001). [https://web.archive.org/web/20120326213849/http://www.thederivativesbook.com/Chapters/10Chap.pdf Financial Engineering: Some Tools of the Trade], ch. 10 in ''Derivatives: The Tools That Changed Finance''.</ref><ref>[http://www.analysisgroup.com/eduardo_schwartz.aspx Eduardo S. Schwartz], analysisgroup.com</ref> His major contributions include: the [[real options]] method of pricing investments under [[uncertainty]]; the [[Longstaff–Schwartz model]] -  a multi-factor [[short-rate model]]; the Longstaff-Schwartz method for valuing [[American option]]s by [[Monte Carlo methods for option pricing|Monte Carlo Simulation]];  the use of [[Finite difference methods for option pricing]].

He has published more than 80 articles in finance and economics journals<ref>[http://www.nber.org/vitae/vita667.htm Eduardo S. Schwartz Vitae], nber.org</ref> and with [[Lenos Trigeorgis]] is an author of ''Real Options and Investment Under Uncertainty''. His recent research focuses on the pricing of [[Internet]] companies, [[asset allocation]] issues, evaluation of natural resource investments, the [[stochastic]] behavior of [[commodity|commodity prices]], and valuation of patent-protected R&D projects.<ref>[http://www.anderson.ucla.edu/x1923.xml Home page at UCLA]</ref>

He has served as [[associate editor]] for more than a dozen of journals, including ''[[Journal of Finance]]'', ''[[Journal of Financial Economics]]'' and ''Journal of Financial and Quantitative Analysis''. He is a research associate of the [[National Bureau of Economic Research]] and is a former president of the [[Western Finance Association]] and the [[American Finance Association]].

Professor Schwartz received a [[B.Eng.]] (1963) in [[Industrial Engineering]] from the [[University of Chile]], and an [[M.Sc.]] (1973) and [[Ph.D.]] (1975; supervisor: [[Michael Brennan (finance)|Michael Brennan]]) both in [[Business Administration]] from the [[University of British Columbia]].

[[Chagai-I|Chagai Medal]] (1998) | signature = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} '''Tasneem Mohammad Shah''' ({{lang-ur|{{Nastaliq| تسنیم محمد شاه}}}}), [[Sitara-i-Imtiaz|SI]], [[Tamgha-i-Imtiaz|TI]], is a Pakistani scientist and a prominent mathematician who has made pioneering and instrumental research and contributions to the field of [[computational fluid dynamics]] (CFD) at [[A. Q. Khan Research Laboratories|Dr. A. Q. Khan Research Laboratories]] (KRL). Trained as an [[mathematical sciences|applied mathematician]], his contributions include [[differential geometry]], [[numerical analysis]], [[information security]], [[CFD-DEM model]], [[hydrodynamics]] (of explosions), [[computer science]], [[fluid mechanics]], [[Vacuum Technology]] and [[CFD-DEM]]. Tasneem Mohammad Shah was a pioneer and senior member of the [[Kahuta Project]], and, along with Dr. [[Ghulam Dastagir Alam|G.D. Alam]] and Dr. [[Abdul Qadeer Khan]], Dr. Tasneem Mohammad Shah have had worked out in the [[nuclear physics]] involved in [[gas centrifuge]] and the [[Uranium enrichment|uranium]] based-[[Nuclear device|device]]. As of today, he is a [[full professor]] and chairman of the Department of Mathematics at the [[Air University (Pakistan Air Force)|Air University]].{{Cite web | last =Department of Mathematics:Teaching Faculty | first = | authorlink = | title =Faculty Profile Page | work = | publisher = | url =http://www.au.edu.pk/dept_math_faculty.aspx | format = | doi = | accessdate = }} {{Cite web | last =Department of Mathematics | first = | authorlink = | title =Chair, Department of Mathematics | work = | publisher = | url =http://www.au.edu.pk/view_faculty_page.aspx?id=233 | format = | doi = | accessdate = }} ==Biography== Shah was born in Pakistan and had moved to Islamabad for his studies. He attended the jubilant and newly founded university, the [[Quaid-i-Azam University]] where he received his undergraduate degree in mathematics from there. He did his MSc, [[Master of Philosophy|M. Phil.]] from Quaid-I-Azam University, followed by his DPhil in mathematics from [[University of Oxford]], United Kingdom.{{Cite web |last = (CCIS) |first = Computational Complexities Innovations and Solutions |authorlink = |title = Prof. Tasneem Mohammad Shah |work = |publisher = |year = 2009 |url = http://www.ciit-atd.edu.pk/CCIS/Symposium_2007.html#05 |doi = |accessdate = 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111007120420/http://www.ciit-atd.edu.pk/CCIS/Symposium_2007.html#05 |archivedate = 7 October 2011 |df = dmy-all }} His doctoral thesis were written on "''Analysis of [[Multigrid method|Multi-Grid Methods]], design, theory and development of [[Algo]].''".{{Cite web|last= |first= |authorlink= |title=Computer Sciences Advisor:Dr. Tasneem Mohammad Shah |work= |publisher= |url=http://research.szabist-isb.edu.pk/sidebar/AuthorGuideLines/IS_Advisor_CS_Spring2010.xls |format=[[webcache]] |doi= |accessdate=2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100715040925/http://research.szabist-isb.edu.pk/sidebar/AuthorGuideLines/IS_Advisor_CS_Spring2010.xls |archivedate=15 July 2010 }} M. Shah came back to Pakistan, after the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971|1971 Winter War]] where he joined his alma mater, Quaid-i-Azam University. His early research were mainly focused and emphasised on [[Fluid mechanics|Fluid]] and [[Aerodynamics]]. In 1972, M. Shah was introduced by [[Asghar Qadir]] to Dr. [[Abdus Salam]], where Professor Salam had delegated M. Shah to [[Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission]] where he had closely collaborated with Dr. [[Riazuddin (physicist)|Riazuddin]] and Dr. Asghar Qadir in the development of the nuclear device. At the end of 1975, Dr. [[Abdul Qadeer Khan|A. Qadeer Khan]] had brought the drawings of the [[Zippe-type centrifuge]]s, which according to Dr. [[Ghulam Dastagir Alam]], were incomplete and the drawings of the centrifuge machine were incorrect.{{Citation | last = | first = | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title =Dr. G D Alam Interview with Daily Asas and | newspaper =[[Daily Asas]] | pages =1 | year =1998 | url = | accessdate = }} Dr. [[Anwar Ali (scientist)|Anwar Ali]] then contacted [[Muhammad Hafeez Qureshi|Hafeez Qureshi]] to re-design and work out the solution of the Centrifuge machine. Hafeez Qureshi informed [[Munir Ahmad Khan]] (who later consulted with Dr. [[Abdus Salam]]) about the problem faced by the [[Khan Research Laboratories|KRL]] scientists. Tasneem Mohammad Shah who specialised in [[Fluid dynamics]] from [[Oxford University|Oxford]], was named by Dr. Abdus Salam for the gas-centrifuge project when Munir Ahmad Khan and Hafeez Qureshi consulted with him. In 1975, Anwar Ali and Dr. G.D. Alam had met with Tasneem Shah in Islamabad, and Shah, with the full backing of Abdus Salam, was accompanied by Dr. G. D. Alam to a secret project in Kahuta in 1975.{{Citation | last = | first = | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title =Dr. Ghulam Dastigar Allam's interview with Daily Asas | newspaper = [[Daily Asas]] | pages = 1 | date =6 December 1998 | url = | accessdate = }} The following years, M. Shah had joined Abdul Qadeer Khan's then-known as [[Engineering Research Laboratories]] (ERL) from its beginning years. Trained as an applied mathematician, Shah was an instrumental carrying out the experimental and theoretical research at KRL. He was the founder and had served as the first director of the Computational Fluid Dynamics Division at the KRL. In particular, he had developed the expertise techniques in fluid explosions—phenomena which are difficult to model mathematically. M. Shah, a pioneer in fluid dynamics, had used complex integrations, and mathematical methods to developed the sustainable method for the gas-centrifuges which he published his work at the KRL. He gained fame in the research laboratory when Dr. M. Shah had mathematically modelled the fuild system in a [[Zippe-type centrifuge]], and have had improved the technology that was brought by Dr. [[Abdul Qadeer Khan]] in the mid 1970s. His developed theories and the experimental research led to an improvement in the devices, and KRL had developed the advanced and newer versions of the Zippe-type technology as P-1 and P-2. M. Shah's principal contribution to the gas-centrifuge program was the rotational dynamics of the 235[[Uranium-235|U]] by using the complex and difficult applications of [[Disk integration|Washer]] and [[Shell integration]]s. Dr. T. M. Shah was one of the key scientist who had helped developing the [[Inertial system|Inertial]] and [[Thermal system]] of the [[Ghauri (missile)|Ghauri missile system series]]. He had laid down the ground work of the [[Liquid-propellant rocket|Liquid-propellant rocketry system]] and formulated the various mathematical theories of the rocket science. On 28 May 1998, with numerous other KRL and PAEC weapon scientists, M. Shah was an eyewitness to the [[Chagai-I|first atomic weapons testing]], at [[Ras Koh Hills]] near at [[Chagai Hills]]. He, along with other scientists, was conferred with [[Civil decorations of Pakistan|high civilian awards]] in 1998, and in 1999. After serving in KRL for more than 27 years, M. Shah had begun providing training and teaching at the KRL to the field of [[Fluid dynamics]]. He established the Department of Cryptology at [[National University of Sciences and Technology, Pakistan|NUST]] whereas he served as its first director. He also established the first IT University in private corporate sector and become the first Rector of KASBIT, Karachi.{{Cite web| last =| first =TechnoMoot| authorlink =| title =Prof. Tasneen M. Shah| work =| publisher =| url =http://technomoot.edu.pk/CCIS/About.aspx| format =| doi =| accessdate =| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20100601070847/http://technomoot.edu.pk/CCIS/About.aspx| archivedate =1 June 2010| df =dmy-all}} He remained Dean, Faculty of Computer Sciences at [[Bahria University]] and established an Integrated Scientific and Industrial Software house for contract research (ISIS). He is the author of 14 Research papers. He is also working for establishment of an HEC project, "''National Institute of Vacuum Science and technology''".{{Cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| title =Prof. Tasneem Mohammad Shah| work =| publisher =| url =http://www.ciit-atd.edu.pk/CCIS/TALKS.html#3| format =(html)| doi =| accessdate =2010| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20111007120442/http://www.ciit-atd.edu.pk/CCIS/TALKS.html#3| archivedate =7 October 2011| df =dmy-all}} ==Research== ===Monte Carlo simulation=== The [[Monte Carlo method]] is a class of modern computation mathematics that analyses repeated simulations of [[random]] events. It often uses [[computer simulation]] to compute the results of [[physics]] systems. Tasneem Mohammad Shah's research applied the Monte Carlo method to the field of [[Thermal radiation|thermal]] [[radiative transfer]]{{Cite journal | last =Shah | first =Tasneem M. | authorlink = | author2 =Zafar U. Koreshi, Sadaf Siddiq, | title =Monte Carlo Simulation in Thermal Radiative Transfer: Method Review, Validation and Parameter Sensitivity | journal =International Journal of Mechanical & Mechatronics Engineering | volume =9 | issue =9 | pages =221–228 | publisher =International Journal of Mechanical & Mechatronics Engineering | location =Islamabad | url =https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:A0yOceRgsF4J:www.ijens.org/1940091%2520IJMME.pdf+Tasneem+M.+Shah&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESgq3P--vydEF0wevFuoDrE1hK-pLFREdMnt6CwJ1VfjCZ4kqmQGMk2632FModbBcNbXllTfuUJ923hreOHTlUwSxD_XRruBouXcOHxDsLOtJFmL25xOOkn0TDdu3-02iymKIy_Q&sig=AHIEtbSYWlZHqySpZnxa7_aFdrjOYe_8iA | issn = | doi = | id = | accessdate = }} and radionuclide enrichment technology. He also used the Monte Carlo method to solve problems in missile development affecting high-temperature combustion chambers and explosive weapon warhead. ===Computation fluid dynamics=== Dr. Tasneem Mohammad Shah was a pioneering scientist in [[Kahuta Research Laboratories|KRL]] who launched the research programs to the field of [[Computational Fluid Dynamics]] (CFD) at [[A. Q. Khan Research Laboratories|Dr. A. Q. Khan Research Laboratories]] (KRL). He made important contribution in the field of CFD and had published numerous papers while staying in KRL. One of his important contribution to CFD while applying the Computation Fluid Dynamics in nuclear power technology. He did his research using [[:Category:Nuclear power stations in Pakistan|Pakistan's nuclear power plants]], notably [[Karachi Nuclear Power Plant]]. One of his major research publication is "''An analysis and comparison of tube natural frequency modes with fluctuating force frequency from thermal cross-flow fluid in 300 MWE PWR''", which analysis the CFD applications in [[nuclear power plant]]s powered with a gross capacity of 300 [[MWe]].{{Cite journal | last =Shah | first =Tasneem M. | authorlink = | author2 =Zafar U. Koreshi, Sadaf Siddiq, | title =Monte Carlo Simulation in Thermal Radiative Transfer: Method Review, Validation and Parameter Sensitivity | journal =International Journal of Mechanical & Mechatronics Engineering | volume =9 | issue =9 | pages =221–228 | publisher =International Journal of Mechanical & Mechatronics Engineering | location =Islamabad | url =https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:A0yOceRgsF4J:www.ijens.org/1940091%2520IJMME.pdf+Tasneem+M.+Shah&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESgq3P--vydEF0wevFuoDrE1hK-pLFREdMnt6CwJ1VfjCZ4kqmQGMk2632FModbBcNbXllTfuUJ923hreOHTlUwSxD_XRruBouXcOHxDsLOtJFmL25xOOkn0TDdu3-02iymKIy_Q&sig=AHIEtbSYWlZHqySpZnxa7_aFdrjOYe_8iA | issn = | doi = | id = | accessdate = }} His publication highly stressed the motion and the movement of the advanced fluid dynamics in a [[Nuclear reactor core]]. In a [[Reactor core]], it is generally difficult to model mathematically the thermal and fluid systems accurately as the core consists of both [[High-temperature superconductivity|high-temperature]] thermal [[fluid flow]] behaviour in a reactor core.{{Cite journal | last = | first = | authorlink = | title =An analysis and comparison of tube natural frequency modes with fluctuating force frequency from thermal cross-flow fluid in 300 MWE PWR (Ibid) | journal =International Journal of Mechanical & Mechatronics Engineering | volume =9 | issue =9 | pages =221–228 | publisher = | location = | url =https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:4gQM2Vj9itIJ:www.ijens.org/1936091%2520IJET.pdf+tasneem+M.+Shah&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESg-lxYkvf5xfu4Nv6UfF-xgO2yzh2O6wa7EzNVurfVgtXdi_bkvvSAijrk7DvwDqWJE9Ke-trzYKGEM5GCvi5w-qmbo5nvDaGt4kv-mBr-XL6in2xo0WRyHVX3o4roKLkcZgTAk&sig=AHIEtbQ4XElNn3nmOsUXoM0JdkNeY9cMxg | issn = | doi = | id = | accessdate = }} Dr. T.M. Shah's publication and studies are considered one of the groundbreaking contributions to computational fluid dynamics in KRL due to its emphasise on physical and mathematical understanding and insight into the fluid flow and heat transfer phenomena in a nuclear reactor core. His teaching and research has brought a groundbreaking change in the field of Computational Fluid Dynamics at Dr. A. Q. Khan Research. ==Publications== ===Conference papers=== *Numerical Solution for Qualification of Thermal Protection System (TPS) Components for Liquid Propellant Rocket Engines. *An Analysis and comparison of tube natural frequency modes with fluctuating force frequency from thermal cross-flow fluid, by Dr. T.M. Shah. *Data Security based on public private a symmetric key. Papers were presented in [[SZABIST]] University by Dr. Tasneem Shah. ===Research papers=== *Modeling and Numerical Solution of Rotating Flows (2003), by Dr. Tasneem Mohammad Shah and Dr. Tahira Haroon. International Conference on Models and Methods in Fluid Mechanics. *Science Vision:A Numerical Technique for the Solution of Navier–Stokes Equations (2000) Tahira Haroon, T. M. Shah. *Fluid Mechanics, A Multigrid Solution of Rotating Compressible Navier–Stokes Problem (1994), by T. M. Shah, M. N. Akhter, T. Haroon *Monte Carlo Simulation in Thermal Radiative Transfer: Method Review, Validation and Parameter Sensitivity, Zafar U. Koreshi, Sadaf Siddiq, Tasneem Mohammad Shah ==Quotes== :{{cquote|''Mathematics is the life line of engineering. Engineering Mathematics has developed rapidly along technological progress. On the other hand, it has always been an important part of the business studies. As a result, developing specialised Mathematics courses to suit each Engineering and Management programme requires dedicated research and effort. The Faculty of Mathematics works in close collaboration with Engineering and Administrative Sciences departments for developing the required courses''.{{Cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = |
